intro: Hapalochilus dolichoglottis, commonly known as the long-tongued lily, is a striking plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It is a member of the Alstroemeriaceae family and is characterized by its large, showy flowers that can reach up to 30 cm in length. The plant features a thick, fleshy rhizome and produces strap-like leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating. Its flowers are typically pink to purple in color and are adapted for pollination by long-tongued bats and birds. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is a subject of interest in botanical research and conservation efforts.
